etymologies: late 15th century (originally Scots): perhaps from Old French tertaine, denoting a kind of cloth; compare with tartarin, a rich fabric formerly imported from the east through Tartary

definitions: a woolen cloth woven in one of several patterns of plaid, especially of a design associated with a particular Scottish clan

examples.text: stripes and tartans have replaced floral chintzes

shortDefinitions: woollen cloth woven in one of several patterns of coloured checks and intersecting lines

definitions: used allusively in reference to Scotland or the Scots

examples.text: the financing proposals for the Scottish parliament amounted to a tartan tax

shortDefinitions: used allusively in reference to Scotland or Scots

etymologies: early 17th century: from French tartane, from Italian tartana, perhaps from Arabic ṭarīda

definitions: a lateen-rigged, single-masted ship used in the Mediterranean.
shortDefinitions: lateen-rigged, single-masted ship used in Mediterranean
